text.p: Former Texaco official Richard Lundwall was to be arraigned in federal court Tuesday in connection with the racial discrimination case against the big oil company, a spokesman at the U.S. attorney's office said.
Asked whether there would be any further arrests in the case, the spokesman said, "the investigation is continuing."
CNN reported that Lundwall had been indicted on a charge of or obstruction of justice.

Texaco has suspended two executives and the benefits of two retirees who were allegedly involved in a plan to destroy documents in a racial discrimination lawsuit brought against Texaco by six black Texaco employees in 1994.
Texaco on Friday reached the biggest settlement of a racial discrimination case in the United States, agreeing to pay $176 million to settle the lawsuit.
The lawsuit charged the oil giant with systematically discriminating against blacks and denying them promotions.
The U.S. attorney's spokesman said Lundwall would be arraigned in federal court in the New York suburb of White Plains, N.Y., where Texaco is based.
